title: Bratz are back after Barbie owner fails to kill franchise

Sat, Jul 18, 2015, 21:56 BST - UK Markets closed Bratz are back after Barbie owner fails to kill franchise By Lauren Davidson | Telegraph – 1 hour 51 minutes ago 24.31 -0.84 
After almost a decade of a back-and-forth legal battle between Mattel (NasdaqGS: MAT - news ) and Bratz-owner MGA, the spunky dolls are back and ready to take on an already weak Barbie 
Years before toys of Frozen characters knocked Barbie off her perennial perch, a gaggle of ethnically-diverse fashionistas known as Bratz temporarily toppled the word-famous doll and now they’re back after winning a protracted legal battle with Barbie-owner Mattel. 
Bratz, which first came to market in 2001, is relaunching this weekend with a revamped look, an extra character and new range of accessories in an attempt to regain its place at the top of toytown. 
The return of the brazen dolls recognisable for their disproportionately large eyes and heads, makeup-laden faces and skimpy outfits could spell more bad news for Mattel , which has seen its share price fall by 36pc over the last year. 
On Thursday, the toymaker announced its sixth consecutive quarterly decline in Barbie sales, which fell 19pc to $130.3m in the April to June period. Mattel swung to a loss of $11.4m from a net income of $28.3m in the second quarter last year. 
Bratz are known for their large heads, almond-shaped eyes and bold fashion sense 
Bratz’s first-time around was an overwhelming success , snatching more than 40pc of the UK fashion doll market by 2004, marking the first time that Barbie did not hold the top spot since records began 10 years earlier. 
Between 2005 and 2007, Bratz was the top brand in the UK toy market beating Thomas and Friends, Star Wars and Barbie and no other toy company since has held the top spot for three consecutive years. 
But in 2006, Mattel filed a 58-page lawsuit against MGA Entertainment, accusing the Bratz owner of intellectual property theft because the dolls were conceived by a designer while he was employed by Mattel. 
At the time, MGA chief executive Isaac Larian told the Telegraph, “It's an absolute pure act of desperation . Mattel lives in a fantasy land. They don't own Bratz and they know it. It's all fabricated paranoia from a company that's lost its leadership.” 
MGA fired back at Mattel, claiming that the toy giant stole its designs to create a new range of dolls under the My Scene brand. 
The overwhelming popularity of Frozen has hurt Barbie's sales 
In 2008, a California judge ordered MGA to stop making and selling Bratz dolls and to turn the franchise over to Mattel, after a jury found in favour of the Barbie owner and awarded Mattel $100m in damages. 
However, this ruling was overturned in the appellate court before it came into effect. The chief judge, Alex Kozinski, wrote, "Mattel can't claim a monopoly over fashion dolls with a bratty look or attitude, or dolls sporting trendy clothing these are all unprotectable ideas." 
The tables were turned in the 2011 retrial, when a federal jury sided with MGA after finding that Mattel had stolen trade secrets from its smaller rival. 
Bratz's return is well-timed, after Barbie has already taken a knocking from the flyaway success of Disney's Frozen-related merchandise, which recently transferred its licensing rights from Mattel to Hasbro (NasdaqGS: HAS - news ) as of 2016. 
The dolls and accessories sector has overwhelmingly outperformed the overall toy market for four of the last five years in the UK, growing 11pc last year to reach £287.6m in sales, according to Euromonitor International. 
It is the second-largest and second-fastest growing segment of physical toys, beaten only by construction toys such as Lego , which have enjoyed an enormous resurgence in recent years thanks to the blockbuster success of The Lego Movie and a string of high-profile licensing deals. 
MGA's UK MD Andrew Laughton and brand manager Nicola Mellor (photo: Simon Jacobs) 
But MGA which also owns Little Tikes, the brand behind the iconic red and yellow plastic Cozy Coupe that is said to be Britain’s best-selling car, and is a majority shareholder in the German maker of Baby Annabell dolls isn't worried about having to take on Princess Elsa as well as Barbie. 
" The Frozen phenomenon is fabulous for the toy industry it thrives on crazes like Frozen, Furby, Moshi Monsters and loom bands," Andrew Laughton, UK MD of MGA, told The Telegraph. "There is always room for new brands." 
And is the relaunch of Bratz likely to drive a nail into Barbie's coffin ? 
"Mattel have a fabulous, iconic brand," he said. "You can’t have a toy industry without things like that."
